items.title: City Housing Projects Call For Environmental Help
items.abstract: Housing project residents say the city encouraged them to “go green,” but did little to help them and in some circumstances, stood in their way.

items.title: City’s 58 Fire Deaths in ’12 Are Lowest on Record
items.abstract: As civilian deaths drop, firefighters continue to be killed or wounded inside burning buildings where no civilians are killed.

items.title: Together a Century, City and Oil Giant Hit a Rough Patch
items.abstract: Chevron has spent millions in recent years trying to shore up its relationship with Richmond, Calif., but many residents still oppose the company’s efforts to repair a refinery hit by a fire.

items.title: Terrorists No Match for Single City Cop
items.abstract: The first novel by the “Law & Order” creator Dick Wolf, “The Intercept” provides a sense of insiderdom in an otherwise standard detective novel about a terrorist plot.

items.title: City Suspends License of Operator in Queens Crane Collapse
items.abstract: The city said the operator had been trying to lift a load more than twice the crane’s capacity at a construction site in Long Island City.

items.title: Pritzker Prize for Architecture Is Awarded to Alejandro Aravena of Chile
items.abstract: Mr. Aravena, who has focused on low-cost social housing and reconstructing after natural disasters, received the honor as Chile emerges as a locus of noteworthy architecture.

items.title: Video Review: Chevy Volt Impresses With Tech, Design and Driving Pleasure
items.abstract: The second-generation Chevy Volt, a plug-in hybrid available this spring, is more efficient than its predecessor, looks better and is about $1,000 less expensive. It’s also fun to drive.
keywords: Chevrolet Division of General Motors Corp

items.title: Sam Shepard Takes Stock of ‘Buried Child’ and the Writer’s Life
items.abstract: Mr. Shepard comments on his play, soon to have its third major production in New York; his upbringing; and the limitations he finds in his own oeuvre.

items.title: MoMA PS1 Names Winner of Summer Architecture Competition
items.abstract: Escobedo Solíz Studio, a partnership based in Mexico City, will transform the museum’s courtyard this summer.

items.title: In Tokyo, Brand-Name Stores by Brand-Name Architects
items.abstract: Star architects have created so many high-end stores in Tokyo that it’s worth visiting two shopping districts where the best item — eye-popping building design — is free.

items.title: This Is Probably the Best Bath in New York City
items.abstract: For $7,000, you too can bathe like a very wealthy person.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: N.Y. Today: When Schools Are Designed for Black Children
items.abstract: Afrocentric schools tend to have higher graduation rates and test scores. Also, what President Trump and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez have in common.

items.title: Those Wild ‘Masked Singer’ Costumes? She Designed Them
items.abstract: Marina Toybina got her big break working on a Britney Spears music video. Now she’s behind the elaborate animal costumes on Fox’s hit show.

items.title: Review: An Aching Ode to Jerome Robbins’s Lost New York
items.abstract: For this essential New York choreographer’s centenary, a Public Library exhibition full of the joy and anxiety of postwar Manhattan.
keywords: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

items.title: How to Design a Home Gym That You’ll Actually Use
items.abstract: As the pandemic rages on, the safest place to work out is at home. Here’s how to create a personal gym you’ll want to spend time in.

items.title: New York Plans to Install ‘Vending Machines’ With Anti-Overdose Drugs
items.abstract: In addition to naloxone, a medication used to reverse opioid overdoses, the machines will distribute free syringes, toiletries and safe-sex kits.

items.title: Could Detroit Become the Next Fashion City?
items.abstract: In bringing an exhibition of creative talent to New York, the fashion label Deviate wants to show that Detroit has more to offer than a quick hit of novelty for luxury giants.

items.title: In New York City Sewage, a Mysterious Coronavirus Signal
items.abstract: For the past year, scientists have been looking for the source of strange coronavirus sequences that have appeared in the city’s wastewater.

items.title: A Classic Parisian Apartment Filled With Modern Design
items.abstract: By placing contemporary pieces amid original features, the architect Sophie Dries has created a space that privileges experimentation.
